The legality is unclear, contrary to popular belief. But rather than have that argument, what you suggest seems like the right *ethical* thing to do.
Do three books, in a series, that build up to the final one, with the most complicated models.
The Works of Shuki Kato: Book 1 (easy)
The Works of Shuki Kato: Book 2 (intermediate)
The Works of Shuki Kato: Book 3 (complex)
and...
Shuki Kato: Zoanoid Dragon

Not that we never will see a book by Shuki Kato, just if he cares about marketing, and he knows how many books have fallen dead in sales to the "realshare disease", then anyone in their right mind with that knowledge, wouldn't right a book
or, just pick 15 or 20 of your favorite and best and diagram them into one book, and release the rest for free on the internet (i vote this idea, it saves me money...)

Yeah, some designers hate it if you make money off of them, whether it's charity or not. I'm not one of those guys and would would think it rather neat if someone sold origami models designed by myself.

There's always the e-book and/or app book route. Or sell diagrams individually for a small cost. It's the VERY rare author who can ever expect to make profits from selling books... and not just origami books!

For the book: I actually have quite a few origami designs, 71 that I documented. There's a couple models models I did around 1999- a bear cub and stag beetle - that wouldn't make my grade today, but they do have rather fun folding sequences. I have enough models for a book like Kamiya's if I wanted to go in that direction; Works of Shuki Kato 1999-2011, lol.

ebook would be ok, but i still don't like them. I like the idea of selling single diagrams. A better idea, in my opinion, would be to not actually publish the book, have people send Shuki the money for the book and he would send it back, that way he would make a little more money (book stores keep approximately 40% of the cost)
There's no question that my best designs were only in the last couple years though, but I'm a bit hesitant to include all of my best models in one book

for those having difficulty. first off, though kamiya recommends 50 cm, i suggest a larger sheet. the model is definitely doable with 50 cm, but the details of the head get annoyingly small. OTOH, avoid using a sheet that is too large. one of the really annoying thing when you are trying to work on the hardest part (the wings) is that the tail keeps getting in the way! if you use nicolas terry foil, i highly highly recommend taping the tail from the point to the breast of the model--the base of the tail gets really thick, and will tear easily during the final "braiding." also, i do not recommend that you use something expensive the first time you try this model. i think you will have to practice it several times before you get the wings to your taste.
It doesn't make any difference which way you fold it. Those layers get hidden inside the wing anyway
use the preexisting crease in 105 to guide you in make 104.

Though it seems the paper I've been using--foil backed parchment paper--works really well. It's very strong, albeit a little thick, but there haven't been any issues yet

steps 174 onward, it does not need to completely match the diagrams. don't throw away your work. proceed. depending on how you did the pleats circa 104-106, it may not match. you should be able to proceed regardless. keep practicing until you get the wings to your taste.

Yes I agree a few minutes after posting i folded a model with both versions in itself, half and half, but still im very curious as to why he changed it. I mean kamiya isnt a rookie hes the best why would there be a change :p maybe im exaggerating

VERY IMPORTANT at step 176. make sure you grasp the center axis of the layers and keep them from drifting as you shift them over the next few steps. the paper is very thick at this point and there is a natural tendency towards drift. the more it drifts, the more it will look different and you will become worried you are doing something wrong.
Since it doesn't make much difference which way you fold it, he may have changed it to make it easier

VERY IMPORTANT, each time you shift the layers at 177, make the creases as sharp as you can. this is hard because the paper will be very thick. btw, the best way of thinking of step 177 is a squash fold, not just a shifting of layers. stick a long, thin object into the pleats to help you spread the layers as evenly as possible. this is very much like step 82 of the cerberus.
I personally don't like how how does the crease pattern, because if your using the paper I used for it, the creasing gets all screwed up

avoid the temptation of making the "shifts" of 177 too large in an attempt to "match" the diagrams. the larger the shift, the smaller the pleats will end up being, and you will have less room to do the reverse fold-reverse folds of 195-6.

ai guys I've ever tried to do this origami video by Satoshi Kamiya 5 times more paper runs tearing, or all the things I pies, or so I Faso several folds wrong, you do not know any video that is with the diagram?
the reason why you want to make the creases at 177 as sharp as possible is because in 178-180, you are simply reversing those creases.

EDIT: Nevermind, I finally figured it out (After 2 days, haha), I didn't realise that the back comes up as you fold down. (You fold where kamiya says, but then the layer in front of that gets lifted up, for anyone else who doesn't get it)
